author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a frog called Mr. Jeremy Fisher; he lived in a little damp house amongst the buttercups at the edge of a pond.

author: Potter
text: The water was all slippy-sloppy in the larder and in the back passage.

author: Potter
text: But Mr. Jeremy liked getting his feet wet; nobody ever scolded him, and he never caught a cold!

author: Potter
text: He was quite pleased when he looked out and saw large drops of rain, splashing in the pond--

author: Potter
text: "I will get some worms and go fishing and catch a dish of minnows for my dinner," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: "If I catch more than five fish, I will invite my friends Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise and Sir Isaac Newton.

author: Potter
text: The Alderman, however, eats salad."

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy put on a mackintosh, and a pair of shiny galoshes; he took his rod and basket, and set off with enormous hops to the place where he kept his boat.

author: Potter
text: The boat was round and green, and very like the other lily-leaves.

author: Potter
text: It was tied to a water-plant in the middle of the pond.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy took a reed pole, and pushed the boat out into open water.

author: Potter
text: "I know a good place for minnows," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy stuck his pole into the mud and fastened the boat to it.

author: Potter
text: Then he settled himself cross- legged and arranged his fishing tackle.

author: Potter
text: He had the dearest little red float.

author: Potter
text: His rod was a tough stalk of grass, his line was a fine long white horse-hair, and he tied a little wriggling worm at the end.

author: Potter
text: The rain trickled down his back, and for nearly an hour he stared at the float.

author: Potter
text: "This is getting tiresome, I think I should like some lunch," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: He punted back again amongst the water-plants, and took some lunch out of his basket.

author: Potter
text: "I will eat a butterfly sandwich, and wait till the shower is over," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: A great big water-beetle came up underneath the lily leaf and tweaked the toe of one of his galoshes.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy crossed his legs up shorter, out of reach, and went on eating his sandwich.

author: Potter
text: Once or twice something moved about with a rustle and a splash amongst the rushes at the side of the pond.

author: Potter
text: "I trust that is not a rat," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher; "I think I had better get away from here."

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy shoved the boat out again a little way, and dropped in the bait.

author: Potter
text: There was a bite almost directly; the float gave a tremendous bobbit!

author: Potter
text: "A minnow! a minnow!

author: Potter
text: I have him by the nose!" cried Mr. Jeremy Fisher, jerking up his rod.

author: Potter
text: But what a horrible surprise!

author: Potter
text: Instead of a smooth fat minnow, Mr. Jeremy landed little Jack Sharp, the stickleback, covered with spines!

author: Potter
text: The stickleback floundered about the boat, pricking and snapping until he was quite out of breath.

author: Potter
text: Then he jumped back into the water.

author: Potter
text: And a shoal of other little fishes put their heads out, and laughed at Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: And while Mr. Jeremy sat disconsolately on the edge of his boat--sucking his sore fingers and peering down into the water--a MUCH worse thing happened; a really FRIGHTFUL thing it would have been, if Mr. Jeremy had not been wearing a mackintosh!

author: Potter
text: A great big enormous trout came up--ker-pflop-p-p-p! with a splash-- and it seized Mr. Jeremy with a snap, "Ow!

author: Potter
text: Ow!

author: Potter
text: Ow!"--and then it turned and dived down to the bottom of the pond!

author: Potter
text: But the trout was so displeased with the taste of the mackintosh, that in less than half a minute it spat him out again; and the only thing it swallowed was Mr. Jeremy's galoshes.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jeremy bounced up to the surface of the water, like a cork and the bubbles out of a soda water bottle; and he swam with all his might to the edge of the pond.

author: Potter
text: He scrambled out on the first bank he came to, and he hopped home across the meadow with his mackintosh all in tatters.

author: Potter
text: "What a mercy that was not a pike!" said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.

author: Potter
text: "I have lost my rod and basket; but it does not much matter, for I am sure I should never have dared to go fishing again!"

author: Potter
text: He put some sticking plaster on his fingers, and his friends both came to dinner.

author: Potter
text: He could not offer them fish, but he had something else in his larder.

author: Potter
text: Sir Isaac Newton wore his black and gold waistcoat.

author: Potter
text: And Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise brought a salad with him in a string bag.

author: Potter
text: And instead of a nice dish of minnows, they had a roasted grasshopper with lady-bird sauce, which frogs consider a beautiful treat; but _I_ think it must have been nasty!
